And ultimately, where most business books fail is that they are either vanity projects or sales tools with little regard for the reader.
If the page does not either provide lesson or emotion, then it serves little value to the reader...
With every page, a business book author should be able to answer, does my reader gain something practical or do I elicit an emotion?
Too many business books err on the side of technical, authors forget that you need to engage and entertain...
A great business book has a good balance between entertaining narrative and practical knowledge, it has to tell a story...
Most business books would be much more interesting and more useful as a series of blog posts...
The problem I have with most business books is that they make me fall to sleep, some faster than others...

@MrMikeSmith Proposed first class taught in high school and reinforced each year thereafter "Business Communications Etiquette".
@mhdempsey @ENHATCH Well, you know us "arrogant dicks"... ;)
@PeterVOrtho My future emails include the disclaimer "your email will be responded to sometime this month based on management's discretion"
And if you are asking to meet for "coffee", offer an agenda as to why it makes sense to meet.  One should not have to guess motive.
People are not "arrogant dicks" because they do not respond to your emails on your timeframe. Folks are busy so make it easy to respond.
If your email is longer than a few sentences or is too open-ended, chances are it will get pushed to the backburner.
Best way to get ones attention in email: very concise email with no fluff that has a specific action at the end that is quick to respond to.
If you do not get a response to an email you sent me, I am not blowing you off, I am literally drowning in work right now.
